definition: on time/punctual (of train etc)/awesome (slang)
first month of the lunar year
straight/upright/proper/main/principal/to correct/to rectify/exactly/just (at that time)/right (in that place)/(math.) positive

point/dot/drop/speck/o'clock/point (in space or time)/to draw a dot/to check on a list/to choose/to order (food in a restaurant)/to touch briefly/to hint/to light/to ignite/to pour a liquid drop by drop/(old) one fifth of a two-hour watch 更[geng1]/dot stroke in Chinese characters/classifier for items

sentences.english: The train will soon be on schedule.
They're building a new house up the street from me.
sentences.chinese: 他們正點在我住的這條大街的那一頭建一棟新房了。

sentences.english: I won't argue with you, but I think you're being unfair.
sentences.chinese: 我不願和你爭論，不過我認爲你是不公正點的。

sentences.english: The meeting will start at one o'clock sharp so don't be late.
sentences.chinese: 會議十一點正點準時開始，不要遲到。

sentences.english: Really nicely, from Episode IV, after the first time in listening.
sentences.chinese: 真繫好正點，由第四集第一次聽左之後。

sentences.english: I＇m confident you＇ve made the right choice.
sentences.chinese: 我相信你已經作了正點確的選擇。

sentences.english: There's an airport bus that goes into the city every hour.
sentences.chinese: 每小時都有一班機場交通車去市區，逢正點開出。

sentences.english: Trains run on schedule without mishap.
We're trying to plan our future.
sentences.chinese: 我們正點想法替將來作打算。

sentences.english: Does this flight depart on time?
Different travelling graphs of trains have different proportions of punctuality in the practical application.
sentences.chinese: 不同的列車運行圖在實際應用中其正點率不同。

sentences.english: Agent: 15 minutes before the plane takes off. The plane is scheduled to leave on time.
sentences.chinese: 飛機起飛前15分鐘，本機正點出發。

sentences.english: If the time is right, however, the sequence of pleasure unfolds.
sentences.chinese: 然而，如果時間正點，陣陣快樂就放欄出來了。

definition: first-rate/excellent (loanword from Japanese 一番, ichiban)
to exaggerate/to be boastful/pompous/grandiose
(coll.) not bad/good/fine
horrid
(coll.) to beat it/to take French leave
(slang) (used at the end of a sentence to mimic Korean speech) (loanword from Korean verb ending "seumnida")/(jocularly) a Korean
handsome guy/lady-killer/handsome (form of address)
to satisfy a craving/to get a kick out of sth/gratifying/immensely enjoyable/satisfying/fulfilling
erhua variant of 哥們|哥们[ge1 men5]
to serve a meal
bad habit/evil custom/vulgarity
It is said that ... (at the start of a narrative)/to discuss/to recount
(of a wife) wise and kind/perfect in her traditional roles
(Cantonese) to eat hot pot/hot pot
to kill time
When you enter a village, follow the local customs (idiom); do as the natives do/When in Rome, do as the Romans do
